service exit of City law firm Latham  Watkins, in Bishopsgate, central London, surrounded by colleagues.The Financial Times quoted two anonymous sources – one close to the negotiations and another involved in the restructuring deal – who said the rescue efforts were unlikely to succeed.The travel company is on the brink of falling into administration unless it finds £ million in extra funds, with the jobs of , staff worldwide at stake, including , in the UK.Mr Raab tried to quell fears the collapse would leave up to , UK holidaymakers stranded abroad, insisting contingency planning is place.Thomas Cook reassured customers on Sunday that their flights and holidays are operating as normal and that “we are working on recapitalisation plans”.Hi Eoghan, our flights and holiday operations are operating as normal. We are working on recapitalisation plans to provide financial stability for the Thomas Cook Group going forward. ^Ben— Thomas CookSeptember , But many, including couples planning to get married abroad, were left in limbo, not knowing whether their holidays will still go ahead.Lorna Clark, , and her fiance, Paul Ruckledge, who is in his s, are due to fly from Manchester to Paphos, Cyprus on September .Ms Clark’s sister-in-law Sarah Cooper, , said: “She’s just in an absolute panic. There’s nothing we can do until we find out for definitethey’ve gone bust. It’s just horrendous really.”Thomas Cook said it would not be sending any more tourists to the Les Orangers beach resort in the town of Hammamet, near Tunis, after complaints the hotel was refusing to let guests leave while demanding extra money.Ryan Farmer, from Leicestershire, told BBC Radio Five’s Stephen Nolan the hotel had on Saturday afternoon summoned all guests who were due to leave to go to reception “to pay additional fees, obviously because of the situation with Thomas Cook”.With many tourists refusing to pay on the grounds they had already paid, security guards were keeping the hotel’s gates shut, refusing to allow guests out, or let new visitors enter.We recognise its a worrying time for holidaymakers and employees.Government spokesman“We can’t leave the hotel. I’d describe it as exactly the same as being held hostage,” Mr Farmer said.Thomas Cook told one customer on Twitter: “A small number of customers were asked to pay for their hotel room before leaving Les Orangers in Tunisia yesterday, we have refunded those customers who paid on their credit cards.”The Transport Salaried Staffs Association , which represents workers at the company, said the Government should be ready to assist with “real financial support”.General secretary Manuel Cortes called for the Government to reveal how much it is prepared to spend repatriating thousands of Thomas Cook holidaymakers.It is understood that Thomas Cook has approached the Government in an attempt to plug a gap in its funding.A Government spokesman said: “We recognise it’s a worrying time for holidaymakers and employees.“The financial circumstances of inidual businesses are a commercial matter, but the Government and the Civil Aviation Authority are monitoring the situation closely.”Unite accused the Government of leaving workers and customers “high and dry” while landing taxpayers with a bill for hundreds of millions of pounds.Unite represents nearly , cabin crew and engineers at Thomas Cook’s airline.General secretary Len McCluskey said: “News of the needless collapse of Thomas Cook is devastating for the workforce and customers. Thomas Cook Airlines was a profitable and viable operation with a loyal workforce.“Instead of stepping in and giving Thomas Cook the breathing space it needed to restructure its finances, the Government’s ‘do nothing’ attitude has left workers and customers high and dry while landing taxpayers with a bill of hundreds of millions of pounds.“Unite will be meeting the administrator and giving our members maximum support while working to match Thomas Cook Airline workers with other airlines that have vacancies.“Unite will also be launching legal action on behalf of our members over a failure to consult on the redundancies that have resulted from the firm’s collapse.”

Western powers to leave the security of the Persian Gulf to regional nations led by Tehran..pushHassan Rouhani criticised a new US-led coalition patrolling the region’s waterways as nationwide parades on Sunday showcased the Islamic Republic’s military arsenal.Mr Rouhani separately promised to unveil a regional peace plan at this week’s upcoming high-level meetings at the United Nations, which comes amid heightened Mideast tensions following a series of attacks, including a missile-and-drone assault on Saudi Arabia’s oil industry.The US alleges Iran carried out the September  attack on the world’s largest oil processor in the kingdom and an oil field, which caused oil prices to rise by the biggest percentage since the  Gulf War.While Yemen’s Iranian-allied Houthi rebels claimed the assault, Saudi Arabia says it was “unquestionably sponsored by Iran”.For its part, Iran denies being responsible and has warned any retaliatory attack targeting it will result in an “all-out war”.The denial comes as Iran has begun enriching uranium beyond the terms of its  nuclear deal with world powers, which the US unilaterally withdrew from over a year earlier.Mr Rouhani spoke from a  at the parade in Tehran, with unormed officers from the country’s military and its paramilitary Revolutionary Guard beside him.He cleric later watched as marching soldiers carrying submachine guns and portable missile launchers drove past as part of “Holy Defence Week,” which marks the start of the Iran-Iraq war in .Mr Rouhani said Iran was willing to “extend the hand of friendship and brotherhood” to Persian Gulf nations and was “even ready to forgive their past mistakes”." width"" "" rel"nofollow"  President Hassan Rouhani arrives for the military parade “Those who want to link the region’s incidents to the Islamic Republic of Iran are lying like their past lies that have been revealed,” the president said.“If they are truthful and really seek security in the region, they must not send region and the farther you go from our region and our nations, the more security would come for our region,” he said.He said Iran’s plan would focus on providing security in the Persian Gulf, the Strait of Hormuz and the Gulf of Oman “with help from regional countries”.Iran has boosted its naval co-operation with China, India, Oman, Pakistan, and Russia in recent years.The US maintains defence agreements across the Persian Gulf with allied Arab nations and has tens of thousands of troops stationed in the region.Since , it has viewed the region as crucial to its national security, given its energy exports.A fth of all oil traded passes through the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow mouth of the Persian Gulf. The US plans to send additional troops to the region over the tensions.

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# WorldUN agency condemns Tanzania for not sharing details on Ebola-like casesThe WHO statement said the lack of information from Tanzania made it dficult to assess potential risks. data-dfpadtargeting"" title"The Ebola virus " width"" ""  " title"The Ebola virus " width"" ""  The Ebola virus By Cara Anna, Associated PressSeptember   CommentsUN agency condemns Tanzania for not sharing details on Ebola-like casesBelfastThe World Health Organisation has issued an unusual statement raising questions about whether Tanzania is covering up possible cases of the deadly Ebola virus.https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news un-agency-condemns-tanzania-for-not-sharing-details-on-ebolalike-cases-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news article.ece bc AUTOCROP h bpanews_fad--df-b-deaeb_EmailThe World Health Organisation has issued an unusual statement raising questions about whether Tanzania is covering up possible cases of the deadly Ebola virus..pushThe disease is a signicant cause for concern during a regional outbreak that has been declared a rare global health emergency.The statement says Tanzania’s government “despite several requests” has not shared its clinical data, the results of its investigations or the possible contacts of a number of patients with Ebola-like symptoms.Tanzania’s government, which has said it has no Ebola cases, could not immediately be reached for comment. The cases would be the first ever Ebola infections confirmed in the East African country.The United Nations health agency says it was made aware on September  of the death in Tanzania’s commercial capital, Dar es Salaam, of a patient suspected to have Ebola. A day later, it received unofficial reports that an Ebola test had come back positive. On Thursday, it received unofficial reports that a contact of the patient, who had travelled widely in the country, was sick and in hospital.A rapid response is crucial in containing Ebola, which can be fatal in up to % of cases and is most often spread by close contact with bodily fluids of people exhibiting symptoms or with contaminated objects.The WHO statement said the lack of information from Tanzania made it dficult to assess potential risks.The Ebola outbreak based in neighbouring Democratic Republic of Congo has infected over , people and killed nearly , of them. A few cases have been confirmed in neighbouring Uganda as well, and other neighbouring countries have been preparing for the outbreak’s possible spread.This is not the first time health officials have raised serious questions about the suspected Tanzania cases. On Monday, the US health and human services secretary, Alex Azar, told reporters in Uganda that he and others were “very concerned about the lack of transparency” in Tanzania.Critics have shown increasing alarm as Tanzanian President John Magufuli’s government has restricted access to key information and cracked down on perceived dissent. Politicians recently approved an amendment to a statistics law to make it a crime to distribute information not sanctioned by the government or which contradicts the government.The World Bank was among those expressing concern at that amendment.

title: 70 year old marathon man dedicates last run memory
story: A Derry man who has been running competitively for the past forty years will take part in his last full marathon next month in memory of former club member, Martin Gallagher.Harry McNulty is one of the founding members of Foyle Valley Athletics Club and a familiar face in the local running circuit.At the age of  he has decided to bow out of full marathons but will continue to compete in shorter distances and will no doubt be seen sporting the famous purple colours of his club as he treks through the streets of Derry or tackles the back roads of Donegal.He grew up in Melmore Gardens, Creggan, and now resides in the Waterside area of the city.The -year-old has run  half marathons and will compete in his st, and final, full marathon on October  in Dublin.Harry comes from a family of seven, five boys and two girls, and his brothers Dessie and Brendan were considered the runners in the family. Tragically, Dessie was killed in a car crash in .“Dessie was the best of us. Him and Brendan were the two runners. Dessie was a great runner at school and then at Sparta where he was captain. He was a very popular fella.“As well as being a great runner he was a great captain. He looked after his charges very well.“Brendan and his we both ran for Northern Ireland and were both very good athletes. Dessie ran shorter distances whereas Brendan ran anything from km right through to the marathon.”Harry was somewhat of a late starter when it came to running, his brothers talked him into it at a time he was overweight in the early s. About a year later he competed in his first marathon in Dublin.He was one of the founding members of Foyle Valley Athletics Club in . At the time they were told it wouldn’t survive six months, but  years later it now has approximately  members.It is an “all ability club” with dferent groups meeting weekly at Templemore Sports Complex and in the Waterside. “Anybody who wants to run will get the opportunity butyou don’t want to compete you can join to keep fit. We like people to compete but don’t put anyone under pressure to do so.”“I, to be perfectly frank, wasn’t brought in for my athletic expertise, I’m not saying I was useless but would’ve been average, but that fits into the ethos of the club.”Personal bestDespite his modesty, Harry has run impressive times over the years, recording a sub--hour marathon in Belfast. That is no mean feat, it requires dedicated training, and, on the day you have to run an average of around : per mile across the . mile course.Harry recalled his brother Dessie spurring him on as he neared the finish line that day, sadly, it would be the last time he saw him alive.“It was the st of May  and Dessie was killed ten days later on the th. I hadn’t enough long runs coming into it and at the latter stages I was absolutely out of it, really struggling.“Dessie was there at the  mile mark and, in Belfast I don’t know anybody, but I heard this voice shouting ‘Harry, get your head up out of your chest! You’ve come through  mile in : you can break  hours but you’re going to have to work for it’.“It just gave me enough encouragement to keep going. He came round to see me at the finish line. “He had just moved to Belfast and wanted me to see his new house but I had come with a crowd of boys on a train and said I’d be up in a couple of weeks to spend the weekend, to do a bit of running and play some snooker.“But he was killed ten days later.”Marty Gallaghergoogletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshTwenty years later, Marty Gallagher, a young prodigy of Harry’s, was killed in similarly tragic circumstances.Next month fty members of Foyle Valley will take part in this year’s Dublin marathon in memory of Marty who died after being hit by a car on the Racecourse Road while ing home on Halloween night.Martin was -years-old and it will be his th anniversary this year.Reflecting, Harry said: “Marty Gallagher was a lovely young fella, very modest, unassuming, and comes from such a nice family.“He was a member of the club and would’ve been one of my prodigies when he first came into running, I would’ve nurtured him, but then he got to the stage where he was too quick for me and I couldn’t stay with him. I’d have needed a bike to keep up with him.”Harry has been fortunate to avoid serious injury over the years aside from breaking his ankle in . Doctors warned that without an operation he would have chronic arthritis and would never run again.“You learn to live with the fact that on the long runs you’re going to be in pain. I was lucky to get away with running the Derry marathon this year.”After a more recent x-ray, a doctor warned thathe continued at his present rate he would need a new ankle.“I wear an ankle support and patella support, but you’re not going to let stuff like that stop you,” he added.CamaraderieSpecial club memories include a time when members competed in the All Ireland Marathon Championship in Mallow Co. Cork, in . They won the senior marathon and veteran’s championships.As winners they had the honour of hosting the competition in Derry the following year. It was a very successful event which stands out as one of the clubs highlights.Harry finished second in the veterans team and his brother Brendan competed well in the senior team.Looking back at other fond memories, Harry cited the Walled City Marathon in , which was the first marathon to be held in Derry for many years.“I thoroughly enjoyed it, along with the London marathon, I’ve done four of them, and the Great North Run, which I’ve done twice.“But the club itself, the camaraderie is just unbelievable. It’s a social outlet more than anything . In terms of the people, not just at Foyle Valley but running in general, there are very few people I’ve met through running that I could say I didn’t like, they’re all good hearted, good natured people, and help you in any way they can. They’re gracious in defeat and generous in victory.“Foyle Valley has a great family atmosphere,someone is training for a marathon they will always train with you and help you through. That’s part of the ethos of the club.”Fitness has become an essential component of many people’s lives as experts regularly expound on the benefits to both physical and mental health.Therefore, the emergence of new clubs, and the introduction of couch to k runs, has been “one of the best” things to happen in the city in Harry’s view. “The people behind these clubs love their running and are so friendly. They got people out who never would’ve necessarily been interested in running, and now they’re doing half marathons and marathons - that’s fabulous.”

title: department weighing medical school options
story: The Department of Health is assessing the cost-effectiveness of locating a Medical School in Derry and said any final decision will require ministerial sign off.The Medical School forms part of Derry’s City Deal proposals and as such the local council is engaging with the UK government to see “ this project would be eligible for UKG funding under the City Deals programme or the Integrated Education Fund.”The Ulster University has been for some time considering the development of a Graduate Entry Medical Schoolto be located in Derry and this project proposal features heavily in the Derry City  Strabane District Council’s economic regeneration plans for the region.With the support of the Local Council the University partners have been engaging with a number of NI Departments in an effort to progress this proposal.A spokesperson for UU confirmed that as part of its latest business case it aims to have its first academic year of enrolments for the GEMS in  .The Northern Ireland Department of Healthis acutely aware of the pressures on the medical workforce across Health and Social Careand its key role in leading the transformation of services set out in Delivering Together.Accordingly, DoH commissioned a Medical School Places Review, led by Professor Keith Gardiner, to determine the optimum number of medical school places that Northern Ireland requires per year. His report, published on  January , raises challenging, long-term, strategic and cross-cutting questions with major financial implications.Amongst other issues, it recommends expanding medical training places by at least  per year, potentially costing up to an additional £m per year when fully implemented. This report is a key consideration of UU in putting forward its proposal for a medical school in Derry.While DoH has been assisting UU in the development of its Outline Business Casefor a Graduate Entry Medical School at Magee Campus, this is separate from any decision on medical student expansion in Northern Ireland. Feedback was provided on  July  to the fourth iteration of the OBC.Any commissioning of additional medical places for Northern Ireland must address comprehensively the full range of available options, with a particular focus on the assessment of value for money and affordability for health and social care, the report says.“For example, rather than simply expanding medical student numbers, it will be important to explore lower-cost measures likely to increase the supply of medics over the short-term and which enhance and maximise the signicant investment currently being made in undergraduate medical education.“DoH is developing a business case to consider these matters. Given the cross-cutting nature and potential for signicant associated costs with the Medical School business case, the DoH Permanent Secretary has advised that any decision on this or other long-term options, must be considered by Northern Ireland Executive Ministers.”It added: “The provision of HE places in NI or the establishment of a medical school in Derry is a devolved matter, however, the Derry  Strabane City District Council is presently engaging with UKG to considerthis project would be eligible for UKG funding under the City Deals programme or the Integrated Education Fund.“The medical school is one part of a wider package of proposals currently under consideration with other draft proposals included that could complement existing specialties at the Magee Campus.“The development of the Council’s final bids for a City Deal from the Inclusive Future Fund is still ongoing and as of August , there has been no official final bid submitted for either funding stream to UKG, including no formal bid to provide funding to a Derry medical school.”googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshPhoto: projected image of what Magee will look likeexpanded with Graduate Entry Medical School by the riverfront.

title: derry trades union council calls public back youth climate strike
story: Derry Trades Union Council have said they are to stand with the Youth Strike  Climate Derry organisation this Friday fighting for climate justice.DTUC have called on everyone to mobilise on September  and attend the Youth Strike  Climate Rally, Guildhall Square, for pm.Niall McCarroll, Chairman of DTUC said: "Young people today are both politically and environmentally aware, the young people organising this event are an inspiration and deserve huge credit for this campaign, however, for any campaign to success it needs support and a radical mass mobilization to get behind the campaign objectives.We need to fight for our planets survival but we also need to look at our habits as humans and the damage our le choices and lestyles are creating."More than  percent of the Amazon rainforest is already gone, and much more is severely threatened as the destruction continues. It is estimated that the Amazon alone is vanishing at a rate of , square miles a year."Bornean orangutans live only on the island of Borneo, where their populations have declined by  percent since . title: door now wide open independent nw university derry university group
story: A spokesperson for the Derry University Group has responded to the report on higher education published by Julian Smith.We welcome the clarity provided by this report and intend to respond in full in due course.At the outset, we wish to thank Lord Andrew Adonis, the Shadow Employment Minister Mike Amesbury MP and the Shadow Schools Minister Mike Kane MP for championing this issue at Westminster, and also the authors of this report.The Shadow Education Minister Angela Rayner has also raised the prospect of Derry availing of Transformation Fundingand we thank her for that proposal.On initial reading, this report provides a roadmap as to how the North West can develop its own autonomous university. The door is now wide open for an independent higher education institution for the North West.It provides us with a once-in-a-letime opportunity for the city-region, as long as we are prepared to grasp it. It is now almost  years since the campaign for a Derry university first began.Specically, the report raises a number of questions, which must be answeredwe are to redress what parliamentarians are now referring to as ‘the last-remaining civil rights issue’.These include:What legislation will be necessary to ensure that the new Derry-centred university will transcend both sides of the border, as regards teaching provision, RD, student intake and administration What legislation will be required from Dublin, London and Europe, to ensure revenue funding for a standalone cross-border university in the North West If a HE provider from Southern Ireland, where student fees are lower, were to become a partner in the new NW university, would fees here also be lower Is there any impediment to the National University of Ireland applying for a Charter to establish a university whose main campus is Derry  The report suggests that the institution seeking degree-awarding powers should be ‘physically operating’ in Northern Ireland. Can Derry Strabane Council be the anchor ‘operating’ partner, with NUI as the provider Can an accredited further education provider, such as the North West Regional College, apply for degree-awarding powers  What processes must it complete Derry Strabane Council is applying directly to the United Kingdom Governmentfor funding for a medical school for the North West. What action is council taking as regards applying to ‘UKG’, and other governments, for funding for an independent university for the North West Can Derry Strabane Council now operate its proposed Medical School with a new HE providerat Magee Will central government now increase the MaSN Cap, which restricts the number of HE students in the North, to accommodate the development of a new university in the North West Can central government ensure that the new independent NW university stays viable by ensuring that the minimum cap for the new institution remains permanently at ,  In February , the Department for the Economy, wrote to UU asking for ‘its rationale for locating additional higher education places in the Magee Campus’. Seven months on, UU still had not replied to its most signicant funder. Given the crisis in third-level education in the North West, and the need for the region to entrust its educational provision in the hands of those who will take it seriously, what other providers partners has Derry Strabane council approached as regards developing HE provision in the North West googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshAs an interim measure, we call on Derry Strabane council to establish a dedicated Higher Education Development  Scrutiny Committee immediately.This committee must meet urgently with the National University of Ireland, Letterkenny IT and the NW Regional College, as it draws up a strategic plan for a new, independent cross-border university.It must also liaise directly, and urgently, with Donegal County Council and the governments in London, Dublin and Brussels to discuss funding opportunities and administrative alignments.There is no time to be lost. These arrangements cannot wait for the re-establishment of Stormont or the settling of Brexit. This is much too important an issue.The momentum is with the North West and with the campaign for an independent university.

title: government report casts doubt magee expansion
story: A report published by the Secretary of State for NI has cast further doubt over expansion at Magee by raising a number of concernsThe report states that in , DfE received a joint proposal from Ulster Universityand Council for a scaled expansion of the University’s Magee Campus to , full-time students from its existing ,, as well as an additional  full time students delivered via the North West Regional College .The proposition was the delivery of an increased supply of skilled graduates, togetherwith regional benefits that could flow to the North West.Planned expansion of the university campus is largely dependent on City Deal funding.At a recent Council meeting, it was revealed that projects linked to Ulster University will receive £m, at least a third of the City Deal funding, which currently stands at £m but is projected to be £m-£m with the Council expected to contribute £m and other partners making up the shortfall.The UU projects include the Graduate Entry Medical School, whose financial viability has been cast into doubt by Head of the NI Civil Service David Sterling. Alongside that are centres of innovation and excellence in data analyticsand robotics and automationand a Personalised Medicine Centre of Excellence .Julian Smiths report says the proposals to expand Magee had signicant funding consequences from a capital infrastructure perspective, approximately £m, and from a resource funding perspective.The proposal would require Higher Education in NI to be placed on a sustainable footing, comparable with England, from which expansion would take place.According to the report, there would also be, as with any requested expansion or increase to student numbers, resource grant consequences of funding the proposed additional places at UU and NWRC, and associated student support costs, circa £m."The £m capital cost was highly indicative and based on an assumed cost per square metre per student."The Department for the Economyundertook initial work to determine how it would look at the case,there was an agreement on how the sector as a whole could be sustainably funded, as any expansion in student numbers would not make sense without this in place," it said.In February , DfE wrote to, and is awaiting a response from, UU requesting that an update be made to the case, according to the report.DfE asked for a more accurate assessment of capital need, which was "very theoretical" in the original proposal and created a signicant cost requirement. It wants a review of the number and subject level mix of additional students required to ensure an underpinning alignment with graduate postgraduate economic need in subject areas proposed.Furthermore, the department requested information around phasing of the project to assessthere are "more suitable break points" in the proposal and a potential to scale any expansion both in terms of student numbers and capital development.And sought the "rationale" for locating additional higher education places in the Magee Campus, as opposed to other geographical locations with further and more detailed explanation in relation to sub-regional economic benefits.This information will be critical to enabling a strategic approach to HE provision and in feeding into any final business case that might be put forward for this proposal, it concluded.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh

title: magherafelt based actor blown away role movie linked jurassic world franchise
story: By Cathal McGuiganA Magherafelt-based actor has said he was “blown away” when he learned he had been cast in Battle at Big Rock, a short film thats part of the Jurassic World franchise.Chris Finlaysonplays American biker Greg in the film and aims to build on this role and some experience as an extra to land more acting roles.Battle at Big Rock was posted to Youtube on Sunday and had been viewed more than three million times by Thursday evening. Starring alongside Chris in the film were André Hollandand Natalie Martinez .Scottish-born Chrismoved to Magherafelt in , where he worked as a personal trainer. He said that his acting career really began when the opportunity arose to work as an extra on Game of Thrones.As well as appearing as a member of the Nights Watch in three seasons of the show, hes also featured in Superman drama Krypton and filmed sword-fighting scenes for the film Viking Destiny, which is available on Netflix.He first heard about the Jurassic World role when a friend tagged him on Facebook in a post from Louise Kiely Casting, which gave away very few details about the role.“They were looking for a biker with a flawless American accent. I just thought Id go for it and see what happens,” he said.Chris said that when it came to the day of the audition in Dublin he was “sweating bullets” and almost didnt go through with it.“Just as I was walking up to the door, I sort of freaked out. I went past it and I said to myself I cant do this just because of the nerves, because I wanted it so badly,” he said.“Then I was thinking to myself, youve come this far, you need to do this. I genuinely thought I didnt stand a chance as I knew Id be up against actors with more experience.”“I went and got myself two pints of Guinness, settled my nerves and went back. I was happy when I came out and thought Id done well but I thought it would just be good experience and that I wasnt going to get it.”A few weeks later the casting agent emailed Chris to let him know that the role was his, but he still didnt know exactly what he had been cast in.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh“I thought it was probably some low-budget thing, but I was happy to get the experience and a few lines. To me, that would be a start at least.”Chris found a few clues about the production by looking up Jurassic World  director Colin Trevorrow on IMDB, but it was only at a costume fitting that he fully realised how big an opportunity he had been given.“They werent even allowed to say it but it was so secret,” he said.“One of the girls said to me that all they tell could me was that it rhymes with schminosaurs and I just knew. I was just blown away because Ive always loved Jurassic Park.”The eight-minute film was filmed in January in Co Wicklow, which means that Chris is happy to finally be able to talk about the role hes had to keep under wraps for months.“The weirdest thing is just seeing my name in the credits. Thats one of the most surreal things,” he said.Chris said that he hopes to find an agent in the near future to help him land more roles. He believes that a talent for accents hes developed from a young age can help him secure some great parts.“Accents have always been something that comes naturally to me. Even when I was only about four or five years old, I would talk to myself in the mirror and try out lots of dferent accents.”This skill came in handy when Chris played redneck biker Greg with an American accent so accurate that the production crew assumed it was his regular speaking voice.“Most of the crew on the set thought I was an American actor,” Chris said.“It wasnt until Id done my first scene and I asked someone what time it was, that they realised I wasnt an American. They couldnt believe it when I said Id just came down from Magherafelt.”

title: ulster university responds questions regarding city deal funds medical school
story: The Derry News posed a number of questions to Ulster Universityover the continued uncertainty on the establishment of a Medical School at Magee College.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshFirstly, we asked does UU have any update or response regarding the medical school and concerns raised by David Sterling around the need for ongoing funding which UU is not prepared to invest   A spokesperson for Ulster University commented: "Following cross-party political and health and social care support in  for Ulster University’s Graduate Entry Medical School, the University has continued to proactively develop the project, working closely with the Department and other relevant partners. Our responses to any remaining clarications within the Graduate Entry Medical School business case were submitted to the Department of Health at the start of July, following prompt and close engagement with the Department and other relevant partners. Our proposed first academic year of projected enrolments outlined within the updated business case is  .“As the Department of Health has previously confirmed that any decision on funding can only be made by Ministers, the University is not actively recruiting medical students as yet for  entry until that decision on funding can be reached.· If funding was confirmed, all other elements of the proposal for our medical undergraduate degree programme have been firmly on track including continued progress with the GMC, clinical placement opportunities and the development of a curriculum to meet the needs of healthcare locally.“We value the continued support of all those who share our vision for medical education and we continue to work with the General Medical Council, St George’s University of London and local clinicians and partners building on our existing leadership in medical and healthcare provision to take forward graduate entry medical education for Northern Ireland."What does UU say in response to local councillors representatives who have claimed that UU has neglected the Magee campus for decades and should not be given money as part of the City Deal but should instead invest its own money in Derry   A spokesperson for Ulster University commented: "Ulster University continues to invest in the Magee campus, most recently with the state-of-the-art £m teaching block which signals our ambition for higher education in the city, already enhancing campus le and paving the way for enhanced future capacity at Magee.    This and other investment priorities for students have resulted in a very strong performance for the Magee campus across all elements of the  National Student Survey, reflecting the very positive reaction from our students to these recent investments in University le at Magee.  With all four faculties of the University represented on the Magee campus – across health sciences, arts and humanities, business and computing and engineering, we are pushing boundaries and breaking new ground in emerging sectors as a progressive university, shortlisted for the prestigious Times Higher Education University of the Year Award, .“Our contribution to the City Deal opportunity is a signicant step forward in our collective opportunity to realise the full ambitions of this vibrant university city.  Our City Deals proposal will see us apply our expertise to help maximize the city’s potential in this unparalleled opportunity to boost economic growth and prosperity.  In our continued collaboration with industry partners, we look forward to driving innovation in personalised medicine, cognitive analytics, robotics and automation, leading to both new research posts and learning opportunities for additional students.  The proposed riverfront innovation hub will build upon the expertise of our first data analytics Institute, opened in  and headquartered at Magee campus, and which cemented our reputation as a global leader in this field. Also integral to the City Deal remains our commitment to establishing a Graduate Entry Medical School in a bid to address the challenges of a healthcare system at breaking point.   City Deal recognises the crucial role our University can play as an economic engine in the North West and is a major boost to the collective ambitions of the city and region.  We look forward to the development of our projects in partnership with industry, civic and educational partners."How much money will be needed in total to fund the projects put forward as part of the City Deal A spokesperson for Ulster University commented: "The funding contributions by project across City Deal and the Inclusive Futures Funds are indicative at this stage, based on the allocations provided by Council, and subject to adjustment as we go forward.  Our contribution of % University funding to the Magee projects within City Deal reflects our belief in the impact they will make, and our commitment to playing our part in the collective ambitions of City Deal.“City Deal enables us to build further on our academic strengths that are signicant for the region’s growth, and to make sure that this expertise across world class research and progressive student learning works hard for the benefit of all in the city region. The City Deal bid has education, innovation, job creation and skills development at its core and each of these priorities are also central to our work across both teaching and research.  We are therefore a natural fit and a committed partner in this ambitious bid.  A continued collaborative approach is essential as we prepare to take forward the projects through planning and design and development of the business cases.”

title: Ardglass to host meeting on future of lighthouse beam
story: A PUBLIC meeting in Ardglass tonight will hear about revised plans for the future of the iconic sweeping beam at St Johnrsquos Point lighthouse in Killough.Senior officials from the Commissioner of Irish Lightsare hosting the meeting at the villagersquos Golf Club at pm.CIL officials say they have tested and developed new technology to retain the historic lens and sweeping beam ldquoto ensure the environmental footprint and safety standards at the site are improved.But the proposal has not secured the support of the Lecale Lightkeepers, the campaign group who claim CILrsquos plan will reduce the range of the beam by up to nine miles.Campaigners say that their drive to preserve the beam includes the historic Fresnel lens rotation mechanism ldquowhich continues to work wonderfully well over a century after it was installed.CIL said that since plans for the future of the lighthouse were first discussed with the local community in March , ldquosignicant research and development has taken place to facilitate finding a suitable solution to the goal of retaining the historical First Order Fresnel rotating lens, while ensuring the environmental footprint and safety standards at the site are improved.The Commissioner says that with ldquosignicant progress now made in this regard, engineering works at the Killough site mdash planned for  mdash include the retention of the rotating lens, the necessary removal of ldquohighly toxic mercury from the site and the discontinuation of an inefficient diesel generator which ldquois best practice and standard across all Irish Lightsrsquo sites.CIL insists that it wants to safeguard the historic Killough site and has now developed and tested new technology to achieve a ldquosustainable solution that will enable retention of the historic lens and sweeping beam at St. Johnrsquos Point.Campaigners say that while they accept there is some concession on CILrsquos part in proposing to keep the sweeping beam at the lighthouse, they have been informed by the Commissioner that its range will be reduced.They also claim that the beamrsquos iconic ldquoloom will be lost, robbing the lighthouse of what they describe as its ldquointangible heritage.The Lecale Lightkeepers say Newry Mourne and Down Council has already voted unanimously to protect the sweeping beamrsquos current mechanism and trustrsquos that CIL will not be given planning permission to proceed with its proposal.ldquoThe lighthouse is a listed building and its character, the light, must be protected, declared the campaignersrsquo spokesperson.ldquoWith the loss of the historic lights at Fastnet, Mew and Tory it is even more vital that St Johnrsquos Point should be kept for heritage purposes. Moreover, it is a beautul feature of our nocturnal landscape, much loved by the local communities.The Lecale Lightkeepers have also confirmed this week they have been invited to make a presentation to Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee on October  in Newry..prettyPhoto

title: Aughlisnafin take place in JFC final
story: AUGHLISNAFIN booked their place in a historic first ever county championship final since their reformation in  at Clonduff on Friday night.Three times on the wrong end of a semi-final result, this was one they will surely savour.The lsquoFin led by four point at half-time and despite only two points between the teams in the end, they could have had another three goals.The lsquoFin started the game on the front foot and nearly had the ball in the Dundrum net inside the first minute when Adam Garland palmed the ball inches over the crossbar, but it was an important opening score, nonetheless.Experienced campaigner Paul Flanagan curled over a minute later to double the lsquoFinrsquos advantage. In the fth minute a free was given away by the lsquoFin defence and Cormac Venney slotted over from the m line.In the sixth minute a superb full-pitch move from the lsquoFin was finished by Breannain McComiskey, restoring the two-point lead.A minute later Garland was clinical when he drove to the net to put the lsquoFin firmly in the driving seat. Shea Croskery raced through moments later and drove for goal, but saw his effort go wide and Dundrumrsquos relief was palpable.Instead of going eight points behind, Dundrum did well to re-group and points from Aidan Fegan and a second Venney free cut the deficit back to three points.Oran Flanagan sent over the next three points in the second quarter of the game with Glavin doing the same for Dundrum. Garland and Croskery also raised the white flag with their strikes to leave the lsquoFin with a half-time lead of - to -.Fegan got the first point of the second half for Dundrum with three minutes gone and a third free kick of the game was landed by Venney by the end of the third quarter.While the lsquoFin had not yet scored, it wasnrsquot for the want of trying as a few opportunities were missed and Dundrum lsquokeeper Eamon King pulled off a superb double save, the first from Croskery and the follow up from Chris Doran.Oran Flanagan was having a good game and he sent over his fourth point of the match and a superb effort from Shane McCann restored the lsquoFinrsquos four point half-time advantage with ten minutes remaining.Dundrum continued to threaten, but other than two more excellent points from their standout player Kyle Glavin, the lsquoFin defence held strong and kept the dangerous duo of Venney and Fegan scoreless the remainder of the game.Dundrum half forward Fegan was sent to the line after getting a second yellow in the final throes of the game. Excellent game management from the lsquoFin as they saw out a first ever championship win over their derby rivals.Impressive performances from Garland and Flanagan in attack while in defence the full back line of Brannigan, Dillon and Willoughby was superb with McComiskey putting in a big sht on the .Dundrum were best served by Eamon King in goal, Hurley, McShane in defence and their key forward Glavin.Dundrum: E King, R Carey, R McGuigan, C Miskelly, T McShane, J Hurley, A Doyle, N Rogers, Odhran McKibbin, P Curry, A Fegan , K Glavin , Oisisn McKibbin, C Venney , C Mulholland. Subs: M Coughlan, D McComiskey.Aughlisnafin: C Croskery, J Brannigan, T Dillon, S Willoughby, O OrsquoToole, S Fitzsimmons, S McCann , D Steele, O Flanagan , S Croskery , C Doran, B McComiskey , P Flanagan , A Garland , M Stratton. Subs: R Quinn, S Mooney, R Murphy, B Ogle, C Dillon, R Feenan, J McCawley, B Willoughby..prettyPhoto

title: Ballykinler Cadets get ready for fun times
story: BALLYKINLER Army Cadets began a new school term armed with a fortnight of fun-filled memories gained at their annual camp in Liverpool over the summer.Every cadet took part in a packed programme of sport, adventure and outdoor pursuits which helped them build confidence, resilience and make new friendships.Colonel Sam McCammond, Commandant of nd Battalion Army Cadet Force NI, said parents know how dficult it can be to prise teenagers away from social media and into the fresh air, explaining that the young people ldquoshowed a real appetite for the great outdoors.He continued: ldquoThe Ballykinler Cadets were up for every challenge we threw at them, bringing incredible energy and enthusiasm and good humour to all kinds of new sports and outdoor pursuits.ldquoThey may be out of school, but at the annual camp they were learning something new every day as well as making lasting and supportive friendships.ldquoProviding those opportunities, complete with expert tuition and supportive, professional supervision would usually stretch most family budgets, but thankfully the camp is affordable fun for all, he said.ldquoAs a matter of policy, we aim to ensure all our activities are either low cost or totally free. We even provide free unorms.Ballykinler Cadets meet every Wednesday at the cadet training centre at pm. Potential new members are welcome to come along to see cadet le for themselves.To find out more about cadet membership or to arrange a visit log on to www.reservesandcadetsni.org.uk.prettyPhoto

title: Belfast Gospel Choir set for music concert
story: A HOST of top raffle prizes, including a pound travel voucher, are up for grabs in next weekendrsquos fundraising concert in Downpatrick featuring the Belfast Community Gospel Choir.The September  event mdash in aid of Cancer Focus NI mdash is being organised by sisters Emma and Evie Telford in memory of their mum Lorna.The Quoile Bar and Bistro at the Strangford Road is the venue for the concert which is being sponsored by Phoenix Natural Gas.Next Saturdayrsquos event takes place just days after the fth anniversary of Mrs Telfordrsquos passing following a long battle with lung cancer, despite being a non-smoker.Emma and Evie have organised several events in aid of Cancer Focus, raising thousands pounds for the organisation as their way of giving something back to the charity which provided key support to them at a particularly challenging time in their lives.All proceeds from the forthcoming concert go directly to a charity which has worked with many families across the district.Emma and Evie have also produced a fundraising concert programme which has been generously supported by a number of local businesses, with the sisters particularly grateful for the generosity they have been shown.In addition to the pound holiday voucher, kindly sponsored by Downe Travel, the other prizes include a pound voucher for The Cuan Restaurant in Strangford, pound voucher for the Millbrook Lodge Hotel in Ballynahinch, afternoon tea at Newcastlersquos Burrendale Hotel and the Old Post Office in Lisbane, luncheon voucher for the Smugglerrsquos Table in Killyleagh and a day family pass to the stunning Montalto Estate in Ballynahinch.Other prizes include vouchers for McBridersquos Fashions of the Temple and Ritarsquos Fashions in Downpatrick, meat vouchersfor IK Meats and McGreevyrsquos butchers, also Downpatrick and pound voucher for Picnic in Killyleagh.Tickets for a Belfast Giants ice hockey match, W family pass, pound voucher for the Beau Visage beauty salon in Downpatrick and a facial and massage at the No  Day Spa in the town are also up for grabs, alongside two tickets for the Omniplex Cinema in Downpatrick.Tickets priced pound. for the September  concert featuring the Belfast Community Gospel Choir which starts at .pm are available at Down Recorder reception or from Davidor Emma Telford .A limited number of tickets will be available to purchase on the night as will a number of childrenrsquos tickets priced pound. Tickets are also available on line via the Cancer Focus website or contact charity representative Barbara Long, telephone , email barbaralong@cancerfocusni.org.On the night of the concert, parking will be available at Down Hockey Clubrsquos Malone Park ground which is opposite the entrance to the Quoile Bar and Bistro..prettyPhoto

title: Bold Bethany strikes gold yet again in London
story: SEAFORDE golden girl Bethany Firth completed a four-medal haul at the last weekrsquos World Para-swimming Championships.The  year-old finished the London meet with a silver medal in the m on Saturday to add to m backstroke and mixed freestyle relay gold medals plus a m freestyle silver.Firth was badly hindered by a shoulder injury in Saturdayrsquos final as she finished four seconds behind her Russian rival Valeriia Shabalina.Despite winning four Paralympic gold medals during her career, Firth went into these championships having never clinched a world title.She won three silver medals at the  world championships in Montreal, but after missing the  championships through injury, was unable to compete at the  championships in Mexico after the British team pulled out following an earthquake in the country.Firth, who recovered from a long-term shoulder injury to represent Great Britain at the London Aquatics Centre, battled through ing pain to touch the wall in .:. to win silver.ldquoMy injury started to come back after this morning so I was so happy to even be in the final, let alone come away with a silver medal, said Firth.ldquoIrsquom so happy with that swim. I couldnrsquot ask for more. I was really happy with my heat time so going past that in the final made me really happy.ldquoItrsquos been a great week not only for me, but for Great Britain as a whole, added Firth.ldquoWersquove had so many younger swimmers here and Irsquom really hoping they have been inspired to continue succeeding by this event. Irsquove really enjoyed my experience here and Irsquom looking forward to building ahead of Tokyo ..prettyPhoto

title: Call for pitch upgrade at Dunleath Park
story: THE Downpatrick Youth League has made an impassioned plea for an urgent upgrade of pitches at Dunleath Park.The league says it has been operating with sub-standard facilities for over  years and is calling for immediate action.The league currently has the use of five pitches at Dunleath Park, which are used for games at U-, U-, U- and development levels.The slightest sign of rain iniably means that all but two of the pitches become unplayable and heavier showers shut the park completely.In addition to flooding, there is also the additional problem of raw sewage bubbling to the surface in places.In recent years, the league has been forced to play games in Newcastle, Castlewellan, Drumaness, Crossgar Strangford, Killough and Ardglass.League officials say an obvious solution would be to convert the currently unused all-weather shale pitch into a G facility.League secretary Kevin Torney said: ldquoWe believe that the pitch should be upgraded to a G facility with floodlights and a perimeter fence. The upgrading of the pitch is certainly sustainable financially, given the amount of usage it would get.ldquoWe have lost  teams to other leagues in the past few years and they have all cited poor facilities as their main reason for moving to play in the the Lisburn or South Belfast Leagues, he added.Mr Torney said it was essential that proper facilities were put in place to enable the league to avoid weekly postponements of games.ldquoWe are left every year with a fixture congestion because of postponements and in order to arrest the haemorrhaging of clubs from the league we must address this issue immediately.The league are being supported by South Down MP Chris Hazzard, who has called on Newry, Mourne and Down Council to ldquofinally deliver fit for purpose pitches for the local community in Downpatrick.He continued: ldquoThe current provision of sports pitches at Dunleath Park is nothing short of a disgrace.ldquoDunleath Park is used extensively by the Downpatrick Youth Football League with hundreds of young footballers playing each weekend, but yet againthis week, parts of the pitches have been closed to the public as raw sewage has come to the surface.ldquoIt is an absolute shame that in the shadow of our fantastic new leisure centre here in Downpatrick our local young people are expected to make do with substandard pitches that not only flood for most of the winter months, but are regularly polluted with raw sewage.Mr Hazzard believes that Downpatrick deserves much better treatment.ldquoAs the county town, Downpatrick deserves to have the very best in local sports provision, and that simply isnrsquot the case at the moment.ldquoIt is deeply disappointing that so many of our young footballers are left to travel to Lisburn and Belfast each weekend to play football. That must not be allowed to continue.Mr Hazzard added: ldquoWhilst there is no getting away from the fact that Dunleath Park is in a flood plain area, I would have sympathy with local sports clubs that feel that this is too easily put up as a hurdle to any investment, and that the council should actively consider a range of solutions in order to deliver suitable facilities.ldquoI want to thank those local sports clubs and Downpatrick Youth League representatives who continue to work tirelessly in order to provide local sporting opportunities for our young people and I will now be making representation to senior council management in order to make all their voices heard..prettyPhoto

title: Castlewellan forest cycle in the park family event in aid of Knockevin Special School
story: ALL roads lead to Castlewellan Forest Park this Sunday for a special event to raise money for Knockevin Special School in Downpatrick and celebrate the benefits of cycling for everyone.The lsquocycle in the parkrsquo event is being organised by the schoolrsquos Parent Staff Association to raise funds to help purchase new bikes for pupils to help them experience nature and the great outdoors.Sundayrsquos all ability event mdash which runs from am until pm ndash is being billed as a celebration of cycling and will have something for families and special needs adventurers, hard core mountain bikers, club riders, children and young people.The event is being hosted by the Kilmegan Velo Cycling Club with its chairman, Sean Warnock, inviting all cyclists to make their way to the forest park for the event.He said: ldquoThe aim is to get families and friends to experience cycling in a safe setting but full of adventure and we have events for all abilities.ldquoThere will be family trail quests, agility skills for kids, a full time-trial on the red trails, special needs bikes and a Sunday club fuel stop. We have something for everyone and McConveys Cycles in Belfast have given us a professional bike mechanic for the day so you can get a once over and some advice for free.Knockevin parent, Tara Haughian mdash who is also helping organise the event mdash said she has been ldquostunned by the reaction and the generosity the event has inspired.ldquoWe have had the most amazing offers, donations, and assistance from all corners, she revealed. ldquoVouchers, cash prizes, food, volunteers, it really is inspiring to see how much people want to help make it a success.ldquoIrsquom a parent of Ted, a child at Knockevin and the chance for him to take part in an event like this alongside other children means a lot. Irsquom especially looking forward to the family trail quest the chance to get your family or a mix of friends to head off and experience the beauty of this natural setting is fantastic.ldquoTara, who is part of the Downpatrick schoolrsquos Parent Staff Association, said everyone is grateful to Kilmegan VC for fundraising for Knockevin.ldquoWe are amazed at the generosity of all our sponsors, donators, volunteers. We have tried to keep a complete list on our Facebook page, but it keeps growing, she revealed.ldquoItrsquos great that children, young people and adults with physical or learning disabilities visiting the forest park can have the opportunity to attend an event like this and get the chance to try out an adapted bike.ldquoWe are very grateful to Newry, Mourne and Down Council for letting Kilmegan Velo Club to use the adapted bikes. We have a few trikes and hand bikes in Knockevin, but itrsquos not enough and their upkeep can also be challenging.Looking ahead to Sunday Tara added: ldquoSome people may want only a short discovery session on one of the adapted bikes and we are very grateful to the Forest Service for the use of a quieter smoother surface area to let people have a gentle introduction to cycling. For others feeling a bit more confident, a lakeside cycle might appeal with volunteers on hand to help.Velo Club member, Michael Donnelly, is encouraging those into their mountain biking to put their name down for the Red Trail time trial. He said Kilmegan VC volunteers will clock the riders with a pound McConvey Cycles voucher up for grabs.Michael said the Kilmegan Clubrsquos junior section is running an agility course sohills and thrills arenrsquot necessarily for peoplersquos cup of tea, they might want to practice a few skills and warm up on the agility course ahead of the agility obstacle course. Sundayrsquos event has also secured the back of Disability Sport NI is delighted this event is happening.Organisers have laid on a range of refreshments with donations with Shimna College parents helping with these on the day, with healthy fruit snacks provided by The Fresh Food Centre, in Castlewellan and Hales Fruit and Veg in Newcastle.For more information about the event email kilmeganvc@gmail.prettyPhoto

title: Council’s £12m outlay to spend a penny
story: PUBLIC toilets throughout Newry, Mourne and Down Council area are to feature in a pound.m upgrade.The news has been welcomed by Slieve Croob councillors Roisin Howell, Cathy Mason and Alan Lewis with the investment part of a major review of current and future provision.Cllr Mason said that as there was only one public convenience facility in Castlewellan, the news was particularly welcome.ldquoAs we are all aware, the district is crying out for more and better quality toilet facilities, she said.ldquoWithin my own area I know there is a need for improved toilet facilities, for example in Drumaness where we have two fantastic play parks which are used by not only local children but also neighbouring communities. At the minute they have use of the facilities within the Dan Rice Hall, however, this is dictated by its opening hours.ldquoWhilst myself and Cllr Howell welcome this news, we would urge the council to ensure it as provision within its strategy for the prevention of vandalism, which is a scourge in all of our communities.Cllr Howell urged the council to pay special attention to the Dundrum area which does not a public convenience as yet.This is something that I have been lobbying for during my time in council, she said.ldquoDundrum is a bustling tourist village which attracts many visitors and is therefore crying out for this facility. Numerous residents and business owners in Dundrum and surrounding areas have contacted me regarding this issue.Cllr Howell added: ldquoFor too long, Dundrum has been overlooked. I really hope the council will take note of this when undertaking these upgrades. I would hope that a facility like this would cater for the needs of all sectors of the community and the council will take into consideration the requirements of those with disabilities.Cllr Lewis said toilets for Dundrum needed to be a priority for the council.He said: ldquoDundrum is punching well above its weight in terms of tourism so we as a council must ensure that we are encouraging and aiding tourism by ensuring that basic amenities are available.ldquoI have asked council officials to make contact with other departments and agencies to investigate the possibility of land being leased or purchased within Dundrum village, andland is identied then Dundrum must be a spending priority, the village has waited long enough.ldquoI would be extremely disappointedDundrum did not benefit from this tremendous investment in public conveniences across our district..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C September 18%2C 1979
story: KILLOUGH mdash Down council officials are racing against the clock to bring Killough harbour into public ownership before the end of the year.If they fail to beat the December  deadline they could lose Government sanction to carry out a restoration scheme to establish the harbour as a yachting centre.Solicitors have already been briefed to draw up papers to vest a large chunk of harbour property mdashbut vesting procedure can take, on average, six months to complete, and Killough is not going to be an easy one.The Department of Commerce is offering  per cent grand-aid to local authorities to improve small harbours mdash provided they are in public ownership and schemes agreed by the end of the year.The problem at Killough is that nobody knows who owns the ious bits and pieces of land around the harbour and even after a six-year search there are still disputes and legal wrangles surrounding title deeds.Most of the land formerly belonged to the Bangor Estate but a number of people have claimed to have bought portions from the Estate years ago. Title deeds, usually the easiest of documents to trace, have become impossible to track down.Three people are laying claim to the pier alone and a legal row is pending about whether a contract was broken over the sale of pier some time ago.Against this backcloth, Down council official have been trying to bring the harbour into public ownership since the publication of the Governmentrsquos cash-help promise in July . Before then they had already spent four years attempting to trace owners.This week councillors decided to end their six-year search and apply for vesting mdash a statutory power which enables a Government department to buy land compulsorily, despite the wishes of the owner.But they were warned by council administrative officer, Mr Owen OrsquoConnor, that it would be a dficult vesting order and he could not guarantee that the whole of the inner bay of Killough would be acquired before December.The last-ditch attempt to beat the deadline was sparked off by Downpatrick councillor, Mr John Ritchie, who has been trying to push the council into buying the harbour since . On Monday he was clearly angry that time was running out.POLITICS mdash A suggestion that South Down MP, Enoch Powell, should accompany a Down council deputation to Stormont was kicked out by SDLP councillors this week.The suggestion was surprisingly made by industry minister, Mr Giles Shaw, who has agreed to meet a council deputation to discuss industrial affairs in Down district.In a letter to councillors, Mr Shaw suggested that Mr Powell should be advised of the meeting and,convenient, should accompany the council delegation.SDLP councillor, Mr Eddie McGrady, described the ministerrsquos decision as ldquoodd and said he had never come across anything like it before in his  years in government affairs.He thought the minister was ldquousurping the councilrsquos decision to form its own deputation and he believed the motive behind the suggestion was not altogether altruistic.He told councillors: ldquoWhat is happening is that a new precedent is being proposed to us. A corporate body has almost been directed to include a political representative on its deputation. This will create tensions which this council and district can do without.Mr Sean Quinnthought it was ldquorather arrogant of the minister to make the suggestion and he believed that Mr Powell was like previous South Down MPs, who, he said, had not satisfactorily served the constituency.Official Unionist councillor, Mrs Ethel Smyth, said she would resent it as much as anybodyshe felt the councilrsquos powers were being usurped, but on this occasion she thought it was only natural that Mr Powell should join the deputation.She told councillors: ldquoMr Powell has worked consistently very hard for all sections of the community and nobody could accuse him of working for one party or another. He is one of the best constituency MPs at Westminster.A motion by Mrs Smyth to invite Mr Powell on the deputation was defeated by nine votes to seven mdash a defeat which did not go down well with Official Unionist, Mr William Finlay, who told the SDLP members: ldquoThat was just a political vote. You are not worried whether people in the district get a job or not.BALLYNAHINCH mdash The streets of Ballynahinch will have Christmas lighting this year mdash at leastthe townrsquos Chamber of Commerce have their way.At a well attended meeting of the Chamber on Tuesday evening, it was unanimously agreed to purchase the lights in an effort to brighten the townrsquos main thoroughfare for the festive season.Whether they are erected and illuminated, stress the Chamber, now depends entirely on the business community and townspeople of Ballynahinch.This step forward was made possible by support from a number of traders in the town and the exhaustion of the chamberrsquos present funds.The Ballynahinch committee feel that what other towns in the locality have achieved they can emulated.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Councillor Mr Eamon OrsquoNeill said this week he is still hopeful that some industry can be attracted to the vacant factories at Castlewellan and Annsborough.Mr OrsquoNeill, who has been fighting for Government intervention since the factories closed last month, revealed that efforts have been made to attract new industries.He told a meeting of Down councillors that although nothing had yet happened, he believed that the efforts to attract new industries had been lsquoconscientiousrsquo.ldquoIt is a lamentable situation with two factories lying idle but I still remain hopeful that something will come out of it, said Mr OrsquoNeill.MOURNES mdash A planned motor cycle competition on the slopes of Slieve Donard in Newcastle has been turned down by local councillors.Councillors agreed on Monday that the event would encourage the improper use of the Mourne Mountains because it was planned in an area of outstanding natural beauty.ldquoEvents such as this should be discouraged to preserve the amenities of the area, said a council spokesman.The event, called lsquoEndeavour Motor Cyclersquo, was to have been staged by the Mourne Motor Cycle Club.DOWNPATRICK mdash Army bomb experts carried out a controlled explosion on an explosive device which had been placed on a windowsill of the Northern Bank at the junction of St Patrickrsquos Avenue and Market Street, Downpatrick, on Thursday evening.Police received a call at .pm stating that there was a suspect device at the premises and the bomb experts were called in. Some structural damage was caused to the building.Detectives at Downpatrick are anxious to talk to any person who may have seen the device being placed or who can give any information.CROSSGAR mdash A  year-old Bangor man jumped to his death from an ambulance transferring him from the Ulster Hospital, Dundonald to Downpatrick on Saturday morning.He was James Johnston, of Abbottrsquos Close, Bangor, and he jumped from the ambulance as it passed through Crossgar, hitting his head on the ground.He was taken to the Royal Victoria Hospital, Belfast, where he died about seven hours later.COMBER mdash Sometime during last weekend vandals entered the grounds of Andrews Memorial Primary School, Comber, and daubed a rear wall of the school with a carpet adhesive substance..prettyPhoto

title: Groups to access recycling areas in bid to reuse items
story: INNOVATIVE plans have been unveiled to allow groups and charities across the district to reuse ious items dumped at household recycling centres in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch.To date,  groups have expressed an interest in using items left by the public at the three local centres including bicycles, furniture, paint, building materials and household bric-a-brac.Newry, Mourne and Down Council mdash which is spearheading the initiative across all its household recycling centres mdash plans to launch a pilot project next month which will run until the end of March.Items which groups and charities including the Inverbrena Community Association, Newcastle Community Cinema, Downpatrick-based charity Le Change, Changes Lives, Castlewellan Regeneration and MYMY in Newcastle express an interest in will be housed in special containers at each of the three sites.The local authority has agreed a formal reuse system with the pilot scheme monitored monthly to test how successful it is.Confirmation of the recycling scheme was outlined at a recent meeting of the local authorityrsquos Regulatory and Technical Services Committee and secured the support of local politicians who are keen to help local charities and groups.While a wide iety of items are to be reused, electrical goods left at recycling centres are not included in the new scheme as they are currently separated for collection and separate recycling.Moving forward, council officials plan to work with representatives from local groups and charities to understand their particular needs and the items they are keen to secure for their respective organisations.It has also been confirmed that a rota will be established to ensure that collection dates can be arranged for the groups and charities which sign up to the scheme.Over the coming weeks, council officials will liaise with the ious groups to agree collection days and advertise the scheme. Contact will also be made with the Environment Agency to regulate the reuse initiative.Council officials have also confirmed that people who leave items at household recycling centres must consent to them being reused.Groups keen to recycle items which have been left at the local centres will also be required to submit a business case detailing how they will be collected, refurbished and reused, in addition to maintaining a record of all material removed.Also this week, the local authority has confirmed that it plans to expand a pilot mattress recycling scheme at all its household centres including Downpatrick, Ballynahinch and Castlewellan.The pilot was launched in April and to date, , mattresses have been collected at sites across the district.The council says that  per cent of material in mattresses is recyclable and confirmed that the additional cost to ratepayers for the recycling scheme to continue until the end of the financial year is in the region of pound, per annum, based on recycling , mattresses.It has also been confirmed extending the mattress scheme into   needs to be considered as part of the rates estimates process.Downpatrick councillor, Dermot Curran, has welcomed the initiative to allow groups across the district to remove material from household recycling centres to give them new le.He revealed that a number of years ago, the former Down Council looked at an ambitious plan to turn waste into cash by recycling hundreds of tonnes of unwanted household items and sell them to the public. At the time, it was suggested the move could generate an annual income of pound,.ldquoIt was also suggested that such a project could create a number of new jobs, said Cllr Curran. ldquoThis latest initiative is very innovative and I have every confidence that it will be a success, providing a boost for a number of groups and charities which do tremendous work at the heart of their respective communities.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThere are many positives and benefits associated with this scheme and it is something which would make a positive contribution to the district..prettyPhoto

title: Hot Morgan leaves it so late
story: CROSSGAR Golf Club held its last lsquomajorrsquo of the year when Ian Patterson hosted his Presidentrsquos Day at the weekend.The weather was set fair with glorious sunshine as the first groups took to the fairways and it was none other than club captain Leslie Watson who set the early pace, signing for a superb  points.There were to be many challenges along the way with numerous players getting  points, but when usual playing partner Derek Coulter fell just short with  pointsit looked like the day belonged to Watson.Despite the winds picking up in the afternoon, Tony Morgan, in the penultimate group out on the course, came in with a fantastic  points to steal the glory and win his second lsquomajorrsquo in as many years.Some consolation for the Watson family came with David winning his customary gross prize whilst Neil Brown and Neil Hanvey won the front and back nines respectively.It was also a good day for young Andrew Lennon who won the nearest the pin, longest drive and also had the only two of the day.The ladiesrsquo event also had an early pacesetter in the form of Joyce Dodd who posted a great round of  points and she had to sit agonisingly all day and watch challenge after challenge fall short before finally being announced the winner.Catherine Milhench bagged another podium place this year with the runners-up spot on  points and Joan Dickson also added to her silverware of the season with third place on  points.Jane Baker got the nod for the front nine prize with  points whilst Patricia Magee sealed the back nine with a superb  points. Maeve Fay, not for the first time this season, won the battle of the big hitters to win the longest drive.Mr Patterson voiced his delight during his presentation speech at the great turnout of prize winners and congratulated them all.He also paid particular thanks to the ladies for supplying all players with food throughout the day and to the green keepers for the fantastic condition of the course..prettyPhoto

title: Huge response to plans for £12m Portaferry public realm scheme
story: ALMOST  people have responded to public consultation on a planned pound.m public realm scheme in Portaferry.The project is one of two being proposed for the town, following recent confirmation of a pound, investment in upgrading a number of tourist facilities in the village.Ards and North Down Council is spearheading both schemes, with hopes that the public realm initiative could start in  monthsrsquo time.Recently, residents were asked for their input into this particular scheme which focuses on landscape and civil engineering improvements.Specialist consultants have been appointed to design and deliver the scheme in the heart of the town with a specic focus on Market Square, Castle Street, Ferry Street, High Street and Meeting House Street.The aim of the scheme is to create a safe and attractive route for pedestrians through the town as well as one that celebrates and interprets Portaferryrsquos local history and architectural heritage.Planned public realm improvements include widening footpaths, creating better pedestrian connectivity, improving street lighting, resurfacing footpaths, enhanced street furniture, possible traffic flow improvement and new tree and shrub planting.Other improvements include redesigning the Market Square car park and the use of high quality, natural stone in the Market Square and adjacent streets.A pre-application community consultation event was held in Portaferry three weeks ago and it is hoped that a formal application paving the way for work to start will be submitted in October, with the green light for work to start expected as early as next February.Technical design and procurement is is expected to take up to eight months to complete with contractors on site in September next year.Council officials have suggested that construction work could take up to nine months to complete and thatall the pieces in the development jigsaw fall into place, the public realm scheme could conclude in May .Last week,  responses to the planned public realm scheme were handed over to Ards and North Down Council officials by Portaferry resident Colm McCarthy who was joined by Strangford MP Jim Shannon.He thanked Mr McCarthy for gathering the huge number of responses and explained the resident will be meeting with senior council officials to discuss the planned scheme further.ldquoIt is essential that when public money is being spent, consultation with the public is an intricate part of the process, said Mr Shannon.The MP added: ldquoI am hopeful that the council will be lending weight to the concerns and ideas of Colm and the other  people that made representation through him on this planned investment in Portaferry.The planned upgrade of tourist facilities focuses on an area around the Exploris aquarium.Proposals include reopening the caravan park, additional car and coach parking, a new footpath, public toilet block and the resurfacing of the Ropewalk.It is also hoped that a turbine blade from the SeaGen tidal stream generator which was based in The Narrows in the heart of Strangford Lough and donated to Portaferry could feature in the pound, regeneration scheme.Ambitious plans to upgrade tourist
